facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos 188 to 190 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos 188 to 190 of 1958. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated November 20, 1957 of Andhra Pradesh High Court

anchor.surface_text: . Appeals from the judgment and order dated November 20, 1957, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, in Writ Petitions Nos. 1 of 1956, 19 and 470 of 1957.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court dismissed writ petitions Nos. 1 of 1956, 19 and 470 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, V. Vedantachari and K. Sundararajan, for the appellant. N. Sanyal, Additional Solicitor-General of -India, D. Venkatappiah Sastri and T. M. Sen for respondent No. 1. R. Choudhuri, for respondent No. 2. 1959. August 14.

facts.text: Agreement entered into on January 10, 1942 between Rajah of Venkatagiri and Sri Balumuri Nageswara Rao for annual leases of slate quarries

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that on January 10, 1942, an agreement was entered into between the Rajah of Venkatagiri and one Sri Balumuri Nageswara Rao whereby the Rajah agreed to give annual leases in respect of certain slate quarries within his estate for five years in succession companymencing from February 1942

facts.text: Rajah granted short lease to Balumuri Nageswara Rao from February 1, 1947 to November 30, 1947

anchor.surface_text: On the expiry of the fifth year, however, the Rajah granted another lease to the said Balumuri Nageswara Rao for a short period companymencing from February 1, 1947, and ending on November 30, 1947.

facts.text: On December 10, 1947 Balumuri Nageswara Rao assigned rights under 1942 agreement to the appellant

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1947 the said Balumuri Negeswara Rao is said to have assigned his right, title and interest under the said agreement dated January 10, 1942, to the appelent of the sons of the Rajah.

facts.text: On December 10, 1947 Rajah granted 20-year lease to appellant

anchor.surface_text: The Rajah on the same day granted a lease for twenty years to the appellant.

facts.text: Venkatagiri estate notified under s.3 of Madras Estates Abolition Act 1948 on September 7, 1949

anchor.surface_text: On September 7, 1949 the Venkatagiri estate was numberified under s. 3 of the Madras Estate  Abolition and Conversion into Ryotwari  Act 1948  Madras Act XXVI of 1948 , hereinafter referred to as the abolition Act.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Collector for confirmation of lease on September 7, 1949

anchor.surface_text: On the same date the appellant applied to the Collector for companyfirmation of the lease granted by the Rajah to him.

facts.text: Notice issued on February 12, 1952 by Board of Revenue to appellant to show cause why lease not terminated without compensation under second proviso to s.20(1) of Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: Nothing appears to have happened until February 12, 1952, when a numberice was issued from the office of the Board of Revenue  Andhra  calling upon the appellant to show cause within two months from the date of receipt of. that numberice as to why the lease should number be terminated without any companypensation under the second proviso to s. 20  1  of the Abolition Act.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition No. 287 of 1952 in Madras High Court

anchor.surface_text: The appellant promptly filed a writ petition, No. 287 of 1952 in the Madras High Court praying for the issue of a writ in the nature of a writ of mandamus directing the Madras State to forbear from terminating the leasehold right of the petitioner in the slate quarries

facts.text: On July 18, 1955 Madras High Court ordered Government to hold enquiry under s.20 of Abolition Act on whether lease prior or subsequent to July 1, 1945

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition having companye up for hearing before Umamaheswaram, J., the learned Judge on July 18, 1955, made an order directing the Government to hold, an enquiry under s. 20 of the Abolition Act and decide whether the lease had been granted prior or subsequent to July 1, 1945.

facts.text: Board of Revenue report to Government on October 20, 1955 after enquiry by Director of Settlements

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Revenue caused an enquiry to made by the Director of Settlements who, after taking evidence, oral and documentary, made his report to the Board of Revenue. The Board of Revenue submitted a report to the Government on October 20, 1955,

facts.text: Board of Revenue order on December 27, 1955 declaring lease granted subsequent to July 1, 1945, exceeding one year, not enforceable, terminated it

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Board of Revenue passed an order on December 27, 1955, declaring that the lease to the appellant had been granted subsequent to July 1, 1945, and that, as the lease was for a period exceeding one year, it was number enforceable against the Government, according to the second proviso to s. 20  1  of the Abolition Act.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition No. 1 of 1956 for mandamus against termination

anchor.surface_text: The appellant promptly filed writ petition No. 1 of 1956 praying for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing the State of Andhra Pradesh to forbear from terminating his leasehold right in the slate quarries.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition No. 19 of 1957 to quash Board of Revenue order of December 27, 1955

anchor.surface_text: He filed another petition, being writ petition No. 19 of 1957, for the issue of a writ of certiorari to quash the order made by the Board of Revenue on December 27, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Board of Revenue on September 21, 1955 for renewal of lease under r.47 Mineral Concession Rules 1949

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime on September 21, 1955, the appellant had applied to the Board of Revenue, Andhra for renewal of the lease under r. 47 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949.

facts.text: Board of Revenue dismissed renewal application on May 23, 1957

anchor.surface_text: That application was dismissed on May 23, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition No. 470 of 1957 to quash dismissal of renewal or for mandamus for fresh lease

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon filed a writ petition No. 476 of 1957 for quashing the last mentioned order passed by the Board of Revenue or, in the alternative, for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing the State of Andhra Pradesh to issue a fresh lease in accordance with r. 47 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals filed with certificates granted by Andhra Pradesh High Court

anchor.surface_text: These appeals have been filed with certificates granted by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh .

facts.text: Supreme Court held that lease was granted subsequent to July 1, 1945 and terminated validly under second proviso to s.20(1)

anchor.surface_text: In our view the scheme of the Act is to render ineffective all rights created after July 1, 1945, for a period exceeding one year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second proviso self-contained or requires avoidance not under third proviso; no conditions like public interest or notice needed.

holdings.text: In our opinion the third proviso deals with the termination of rights created before July 1, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the third proviso deals with the termination of rights created before July 1, 1945. The second proviso makes rights created after July 1, 1945, unenforceable as against the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'such right' refer to main section body, not second proviso; different scopes prevent repugnancy; exception for private land only in third.

holdings.text: We do not think that the rule in any way impairs the correctness of the Madras decision. It does not purport to lay down the manner in which such termination is to be brought about. In other words, that rule does not, in terms, attract the operation of the third proviso at all.

anchor.surface_text: the attention of the Madras High Court was not drawn to the rule framed by the Governor of Madras in exercise of powers conferred on him by s. 67 (1) and (2) of the Abolition Act. That rule runs as follows- Rule In the case of any right in any land created by a landholder on or after the 1st day of July 1945 for a period exceeding one year and falling under the second proviso to section 20 (1) of the said Act, the authority to decide whether the right should be terminated or allowed to continue shall be the Board of Revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule under s.67 merely designates deciding authority for second proviso cases; cannot alter statutory meaning of s.20.

holdings.text: In our opinion, there is no substance in the principal point urged by learned counsel appearing for the appellant before us.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no substance in the principal point urged by learned counsel appearing for the appellant before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination valid under second proviso without third proviso notice or compensation; applies to appellant's lease.

holdings.text: It was somewhat faintly argued by learned counsel for the appellant that the Government should have allowed the appellants application for the renewal of his lease under r. 47 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949. The argument is wholly untenable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.47 adds statutory terms to original lease which falls upon termination under second proviso to s.20(1).

holdings.text: The Court must interpret the Abolition Act as it finds it by giving the ordinary and natural meaning to the words used by the Madras legislature and uninfluenced by any pre-conceived notion as to validity of the Abolition Act.

anchor.surface_text: provisions of Art. 31 (6) and 31 B of the Constitution of India read with the Ninth Schedule thereto. Those provisions proceed on the assumption that certain laws passed under the Government of India Act, 1935, did offend s. 299 of that Act and expressly save those Acts. The Abolition Act is one of the Acts included in the Ninth Schedule and is protected by Art. 31B.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act protected by Art.31(6), 31B and Ninth Schedule; no need to read compensation into provisions to save from s.299 GIA.

precedents.citation: A.M.S.S. V.M. Co. v. The state of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: We may, with advantage, quote here a part of the views expressed by Venkatarama Ayyar, J., in delivering the judgment of that Bench in A.M.S.S. V.M. Co. v. The state of Madras 1 . The argument of the petitioners is that the words such rights in the third proviso have reference to the rights created after the 1st July, 1945, mentioned in the previous proviso

precedents.case_name: A.M.S.S. V.M. Co. v. The State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Construction of the provisos to section 20(1) of the Madras Estate Abolition Act; second proviso makes rights created after July 1, 1945 for over one year unenforceable against Government without notice or compensation; third proviso applies to rights created prior to that date
precedents.cited_holding: The true effect of the section can be stated in three propositions: (i) Rights validly created prior to 1st July, 1945, will be valid (ii) such rights, however, may be determined under the third proviso if it is in the public interest to do so and in such cases, compensation will be payable under section 20(2) and (iii) rights created after 1st July, 1945, if they are for a period exceeding one year, are liable to be avoided under the second proviso.

outcome.relief_summary: Principal contentions rejected; termination of lease under second proviso to s. 20(1) upheld as valid without notice or compensation; application for renewal under Mineral Concession Rules denied

anchor.surface_text: the attention of the Madras High Court was not drawn to the rule framed by the Governor of Madras in exercise of powers conferred on him by s. 67 (1) and (2) of the Abolition Act. That rule runs as follows- Rule In the case of any right in any land created by a landholder on or after the 1st day of July 1945 for a period exceeding one year and falling under the second proviso to section 20 (1) of the said Act, the authority to decide whether the right should be terminated or allowed to continue shall be the Board of Revenue.

provisions of Art. 31 (6) and 31 B of the Constitution of India read with the Ninth Schedule thereto. Those provisions proceed on the assumption that certain laws passed under the Government of India Act, 1935, did offend s. 299 of that Act and expressly save those Acts. The Abolition Act is one of the Acts included in the Ninth Schedule and is protected by Art. 31B.
